Fake News Buster: Scent of a scare

THE CLAIM
A message from KR Nagaraju, DCP crime branch, is doing the rounds in Bengaluru's Whatsapp groups. It asks people to stay away from 'sales people' in parking lots who ask you to take a whiff of a perfume that they are selling. 'The paper is laced with drugs,' the message claims.

SO, WHAT'S THE TRUTH?
Although KR Nagaraju is indeed a DCP, he works in Warangal, Andhra Pradesh. "But the message being circulated in my name is fake," he told Bangalore Mirror, adding that he had already filed a complaint.
title: Bangalore Mirror has investigated a viral message warning about a perfume sample scam in mall parking lots. Contrary to the message's claims, DCP KR Nagaraju, mentioned in the circulating alert, confirmed that the warning is fabricated. Although he serves as a DCP in Warangal, Andhra Pradesh, he has clarified that he did not issue any such alert and has filed a complaint regarding the misuse of his name in the fake message.
vclaim: A viral WhatsApp message claims that sales people in parking lots are using perfume-laced paper with drugs to target victims. The message falsely attributes the warning to DCP KR Nagaraju, who has denied issuing such an alert and filed a complaint about the misuse of his name.
